pageData.text: In this investigation, a series of laboratory activities that feature physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical changes</button> are performed. Differences in chemical and <button class='glossary-text'>physical changes</button> are explored and discussed. The type of change that is occurring is identified based on defined criteria, and observations that lead to these conclusions are discussed.

Additional time will be needed for cleanup.The lab may be stopped after any activity and resumed at a later time. If stopping the lab before it is complete, ensure that all containers of liquids are sealed to prevent evaporation.

*Bottled or purified water should be used to remove most of the solids that are found in tap water. Filtered water from a home water purifier (e.g., Brita<sub class=bodySupscript>®</sub> or PUR<sub class=bodySupscript>®</sub>) works well.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Exploring Chemical and Physical Changes

text: Differentiate between chemical and <button class='glossary-text'>physical changes</button>.
Describe features that identify changes as chemical or physical.
List examples of physical and <button class='glossary-text'>chemical changes</button>, then classify why these are chemical or physical changes.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Knowing whether something will undergo a physical or is important when a scientist wants to preserve an item. One example of this is forensic examinations of priceless works of art. Researchers closely examined Leonardo da Vinci’s Portrait of a Lady with an Ermine and found an entire fingerprint in the shadowing effect given to the lady’s necklace. They were able to match this print to two others found in his works and confirmed they belonged to da Vinci. From these fingerprints, researchers were able to learn more about da Vinci all while preserving his artwork.One of the oldest methods for developing fingerprints is the iodine fuming method, which takes advantage of . When iodine crystals are warmed, they produce iodine vapor via a physical change called sublimation. The object in question is exposed to these fumes, which are adsorbed on the sebaceous material that is typically found in fingerprints. This interaction leaves a brown latent print that fades as soon as the object is removed from the presence of the iodine fumes.

pageData.altText: A fingerprint illustration over a background with curls of chemical fumes.
pageData.desc: A fingerprint illustration over a background with curls of chemical fumes.

pageData.text: Some changes are so much a part of daily life that they are hardly noticed. Paints are mixed; ingredients become meals; tools rust; fuels are consumed; and rain and snow form, fall, and then seem to disappear. Some of these changes are physical, and some are chemical.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>A <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> may be associated with a change in the appearance, but not in the chemical composition, of a substance. In other words, the original reactant molecules have not been changed into different molecules in the product. For example, a change in state is a physical change. Solid ice and liquid water have the same chemical composition (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O), but the state (solid vs. liquid) of the H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O is physically different.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a physical change?

options.text: burning a piece of paper
wetting a piece of paper with water
folding a piece of paper
coloring a piece of paper with a red marker
ripping a piece of paper into 4 pieces

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Burning paper represents a combustion reaction, which transforms the large carbohydrates in paper into smaller carbon dioxide and water molecules.

pageData.question: Which is the best example of a physical change?

options.text: boiling water
synthesizing water from hydrogen and oxygen
rust forming on an iron surface
metabolizing water in your body
burning a candle

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. A state change, such as heating water from a liquid to a gas, is an example of the physical appearance of water changing without its chemical composition (H2O) being altered.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change. If not, then it is a physical change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change. If not, then it is a physical change.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Chemical changes</button> result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds. Atoms of compounds are rearranged to form product substances that differ from the original reactant substances. A chemical change can be depicted by an equation showing the rearrangement of atoms. Even when the identities of the substances are unknown, some conspicuous indicators tend to suggest a chemical change:

text: Production of a precipitate, an insoluble solid
A color change that cannot be explained by simple combination of colors (e.g., two colorless chemicals that form a yellow compound when mixed)

pageData.text: These indicators simply suggest the likelihood that a change is chemical; <button class='glossary-text'>physical changes</button> sometimes produce these effects as well.

pageData.question: Which of these describes a chemical change?

options.text: A change resulting from the rearrangement of chemical bonds.
A change in the appearance of a substance.
A change that always produces a solid product.
A change in the quantity of matter.
A purple color-change as red and blue substances are mixed.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a chemical change?

options.text: rubbing alcohol evaporates leaving an empty beaker
plants produce sugar from carbon dioxide gas
two colorless chemicals mix to form a pink solution
two chemicals are mixed, and the solution becomes warm
two liquids are mixed, and a white solid forms

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The evaporation of a liquid, such as rubbing alcohol, represents a state change from liquid to gas, which is a physical change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.  Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.  Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by preparing two colored water solutions, one room-temperature water, and you set up a wash station. 
In Activities 1-3, you will combine different solutions and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activity 4, you will light a tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. You will then melt an ice cube over the tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activities 5-12, you will combine two substances together and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred.
pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by preparing two colored water solutions, one room-temperature water, and you set up a wash station. 
In Activities 1-3, you will combine different solutions and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activity 4, you will light a tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. You will then melt an ice cube over the tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activities 5-12, you will combine two substances together and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: A replacement kit for Exploring Chemical and Physical Changes, item number 580302, can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Safety goggles, a lab apron, and gloves are required at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: <span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including use of appropriate personal protective equipment described in the Safety and Activity sections<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Keep all chemicals tightly sealed and away from children and pets. Wash hands after handling any chemicals.
Magnesium and phenolphthalein are flammable. Keep chemicals away from any heat or flame sources.
Sodium carbonate and sodium polycarylate cause serious eye irritation. Sodium polyacrylate is harmful if swallowed. Copper sulfate causes skin irritation.
Sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid cause severe skin burns and eye damage.
Copper sulfate is toxic to aquatic life.
If ingested, phenolphthalein is a suspected carcinogen, mutagen, and is suspected of causing genetic defects.
Hydrochloric acid may be toxic if inhaled.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep laboratory materials and equipment out of the reach of children and pets.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a chemical change?

options.text: the flame on the wick of a candle
ice melting in the sun
breaking a stick in half
frozen carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) forming a cloud of CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> gas and water vapor
water boiling on the stove

assestmentData.question: Which of the following indicators is LEAST likely to suggest a chemical change has taken place?

options.text: a solid becoming liquid
production of a gas
production of heat
two colorless liquids forming a colored solution
production of a precipitate

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a physical change?

options.text: water forming ice crystals on the window in winter
the bubbles formed when vinegar and baking soda are mixed
a pot roast cooking in the oven
food scraps turning to compost in the compost bin
the creation of plastic from petroleum

assestmentData.question: Breads can be described by their leavening (rising) agent: yeast breads rely on bubbles of carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) produced as yeast cells digest carbohydrates in the dough; quick breads rely on bubbles of CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> produced as baking soda and acid are added to the dough; flat breads rely on bubbles formed by the rapid evaporation of water from the dough as it is exposed to high heat. Which bread type(s) rely on chemical changes to rise?

options.text: yeast breads and quick breads
quick breads and flat breads
yeast breads and flat breads
yeast breads only
flat breads only

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the flammable chemicals used in this investigation?

options.text: magnesium ribbon and phenolphthalein
hydrochloric acid and copper sulfate
sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid
sodium carbonate and phenolphthalein
sodium polyacrylate and blue food coloring

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the safety hazard associated with the 1 M sodium hydroxide to be used in this investigation?

options.text: It is corrosive.
It gives off dangerous fumes.
It is a carcinogen.
It will stain skin and clothing.
It does not present any safety concerns.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize work area.

Prepare two solutions of colored water (yellow and blue). Use the graduated cylinder to measure 10 mL of water, and add 10 mL water to each of two small cups. Add 1 drop of yellow #5 food coloring to one cup and 1 drop of blue #1 food coloring to the second cup.

Pour water into a large cup and (if it is not already at room temperature) allow it to come to room temperature, the exact temperature does not matter at this time. Use 25 mL of the water for the activities; the remainder will be used to rinse equipment. Use only room temperature bottled or purified water in all activities.

To prevent the thermometer from rolling off the counter and breaking, wrap a rubber band securely around it, avoiding the bulb. The rubber band can be moved up or down as needed to read temperature values.

Weighing Chemical Reagents
When weighing chemical reagents, place a weigh boat on the balance and tare (zero) the balance. Add the chemical to the weigh boat until the desired weight is reached. Remove the weigh boat and pour the chemical into the reaction container (e.g., test tube).Measuring Liquids
Use the graduated cylinder to measure liquids. Pour the liquid into the cylinder until the bottom of the meniscus (the curved upper surface of the liquid) is level with the desired volume indicator.Avoiding Contamination
Rinse all equipment with water and dry after each use, including multiple uses of the same item within one activity. Use a new weigh boat to measure each chemical.

Set up a wash station at the lab bench. Use the 250-mL beaker as a waste container for solutions and rinse water, and use one cup for disposal of solids. Fill a second cup with water for rinsing (as well as for use in experiments). After using the thermometer, fill a pipet with water and, holding the thermometer over the waste beaker, rinse the thermometer with water. After using a test tube or graduated cylinder, fill a pipet with water and use it to rinse the inside of the tube or cylinder. Rinse the pipets by flushing them with clean water. Pour the rinse water into the waste beaker. Repeat all rinses twice or until item is clean. Dry all equipment.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack.
Using a 10-mL graduated cylinder, add 2 mL of 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) to one of the tubes.
Rinse the graduated cylinder 3 times with your bottled water.
With the graduated cylinder, add 2 mL of 1 M sodium carbonate solution (Na<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>) to the second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube in the Data Table.
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature of the hydrochloric acid. Record temperature in the Data Table. Rinse and dry thermometer as described above.
Repeat step 6 with sodium carbonate solution.
Combine the HCl of test tube 1 with Na<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub> in test tube. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product (final temperature) in the Data Table.
Observe solution for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack.
Add 10 mL of water to one test tube with a graduated cylinder.
Add 0.3 g of preweighed sodium polyacrylate to the second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube.
Measure the temperature of the water and record it in the Data Table.
Add the water to the test tube containing sodium polyacrylate. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color of the product and any additional observations.
Indicate on the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Dispose of the product in the trash; it may be necessary to throw away the test tube with the product still in it. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack.
Add 2 mL of 0.5 M copper(II) sulfate solution (CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>) to a test tube.
Add 2 mL of 1 M sodium carbonate solution (Na<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>) to a second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube.
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature of the CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>. Record temperature in the Data Table. Rinse and dry thermometer as described above.
Repeat step 5 with Na2CO3 solution.
Combine the contents of the two test tubes in one. Gently swirl to mix, and insert thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product (final temperature) in the Data Table.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place. Save the aluminum dish used in this activity to use in Activity 11.
Place the tea candle on a flat surface away from any flammable materials. Record the color of the tea candle.
Light the tea candle using a match.
Observe the tea candle for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Based only on your observations of the tea candle, indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Place one small ice cube in the aluminum (Al) weigh dish. Record the color of the ice.
Hold the aluminum dish over the flame of the candle using forceps.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations of the ice cube. Place hot aluminum dish on a plate or heat-safe surface.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or physical change has occurred and explain why.
Extinguish the candle.
Save the aluminum dish for Activity 11.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack. Add 5 mL of water to one test tube.
Add 1 g of sugar to second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube.
Measure the temperature of the water and record it in the Data Table.
Add the water to the test tube containing the sugar. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations. Record any temperature change that may have occurred.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.

Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place. There are two parts to this activity. Save the solution created in Part A to use in Part B.
Place one test tube in test tube rack. Add 2 mL of 1 M sodium hydroxide solution (NaOH) to test tube.
Record the color of the solution.
Observe the solution of 1% phenolphthalein solution and record the color.
Measure the temperature of the NaOH and record it on the Data Table.
Using a pipet, add 1 drop of phenolphthalein to the NaOH solution. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate on the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Save the NaOH/phenolphthalein solution for use in Part B.
Place one test tube in test tube rack. Add 2 mL of 1 M hydrochloric acid solution (HCl) to test tube.
Record the color of the HCl.
Measure the temperature of the HCl and record it in the Data Table.
Add the HCl to the NaOH/phenolphthalein solution prepared in Part A. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Discard pipet used to dispense phenolphthalein solution in trash. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack. Add 2 mL of copper(II) sulfate solution (CuSO4) to one test tube.
Add 2 mL of sodium hydroxide solution (NaOH) to the second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube.
Measure the temperature of the CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> and NaOH solutions and record them in the Data Table.
Add the contents of one test tube to the other test tube. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack. Add 2 mL of blue or yellow water, prepared in Preparation section, to test tubes.
Record the color of the contents of each tube.
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature of the blue water. Record temperature in the Data Table. Rinse and dry thermometer.
Repeat step 3 with yellow water.
Add the contents of one test tube to the other test tube. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate on the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place one test tube in test tube rack. Add 5 mL of hydrochloric acid solution (HCl) to test tube.
Measure the temperature of the HCl and record it on the Data Table.
Record the color of the HCl.
Record the color of the magnesium ribbon.
Cut a 0.5-cm length of magnesium ribbon and add it to the HCl. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Discard any solids in the trash. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place. Save the solution created in this activity to use in Activity 11.
Place two test tubes in test tube rack. Add 5 mL of copper(II) sulfate (CuSO4) to one test tube.
Add 2 g of table salt (sodium chloride, NaCl) to the second test tube.
Record the color of the contents of each test tube.
Measure the temperature of the CuSO4 solution and record it in the Data Table.
Add the CuSO4 solution to the test tube containing the salt. Gently swirl to mix, and insert the thermometer.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Observe for 1 minute and record the final color and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Save the CuSO4/salt solution for use in Activity 11.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Cut several pieces of aluminum (approximately 1 cm × 1/2 cm each) from the aluminum dish used in Activity 4.
Record the color of the aluminum pieces in the Data Table.
Measure the temperature of the CuSO4/salt solution prepared in Activity 10 and record it in the Data Table. Rinse thermometer as described above.
Record the initial color of the CuSO4/salt solution in the Data Table.
Place the aluminum metal pieces in the CuSO4/salt solution.
Measure and record the temperature of the product.
Record any observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Discard any solids in the trash. Rinse the test tubes and thermometer with water and dry.
Make observations and determine whether a physical or <button class='glossary-text'>chemical change</button> took place.
Place one test tube in test tube rack. Add 5 mL of copper(II) sulfate solution (CuSO4) to test tube.
Measure the temperature of the CuSO4 and record it on the Data Table.
Using a small piece of sandpaper or emery board, lightly sand the exterior of the iron (Fe) nail.
Record the color of the CuSO4 solution and the nail.
Place the nail in the CuSO4. Allow it to remain there for 1 minute.
Using forceps, remove the nail from the solution.
Measure and record the temperature of the solution.
Examine the nail and the solution. Record the final color of the CuSO4 solution and the nail, and any additional observations.
Indicate in the Data Table whether a chemical or <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> has occurred and explain why.
Pour all solutions into the 250-mL beaker. Discard any solids in the trash. Rinse the test tubes, thermometer, and graduated cylinder with water and dry.

text: Dispose of all liquid waste in sink, flushing with copious amounts of tap water. Return all unused chemicals to the chemical supply kit.
Clean and dry all equipment and return to the  equipment kit.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by preparing two colored water solutions, one room-temperature water, and you set up a wash station. 
In Activities 1-3, you will combine different solutions and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activity 4, you will light a tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. You will then melt an ice cube over the tea candle and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred. 
In Activities 5-12, you will combine two substances together and determine whether a chemical or physical change occurred.

data.title: Chemical change
data.content: Result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.

data.title: Physical change
data.content: May be associated with a change in the appearance, but not in the chemical composition, of a substance.
